text: you have to tell gay men to stop having
sex this Broadway production of the
normal heart won the 2011 Tony Award for
Best Play revival the normal heart deals
with New York at a certain period of
time the early 80s when aids cases first
started becoming known in the gay
community we went to the theater on a
recent Thursday night when the
production offers $30 tickets for
audience goers under the age of 30 to
talk to young gay people about whether
the play resonated for them there's only
so much you can do I mean of course wear
condoms all the time but it's about
being smart and about just being
positive in your own mentality even in
the position we are now with this
disease and the things that are being
done and even the steps the progress
that we have made how far we still need
to go it it's very surreal back then
many gay men were going to funerals
almost every week or every month for
friends were dying of this disease and
there was an enormous amount of
frustration with the new york city
government and the federal government
President Reagan about whether
government officials were taking aids
seriously enough there me a lot of mom
is flying into town not understanding
why their sons have suddenly upped and
died from pneumonia what issue that came
up for some gay men was their discomfort
with the idea of AIDS as a chronic
treatable illness I hate that like well
that's daunting do it
I ended up talking to a family from
Minnesota three teenagers who wanted to
see certain cast members in the play
they come from somewhere where they
don't see a lot of theater but they also
don't talk as much about some of the
lifestyle issues and choices that the
play raised you know I have to pop my
kids use take sex regardless of whatever
but also just hope people of various
life situation have struggled and have
to have a voice and how do you do that
well it was the most struck by with a
number of people leaving the theater
with tears in their eyes who said that
they were moved because they felt the
play brought a group of people back to
life and that what really impacted them
was that the choices that the characters
were making in the play were so similar
to the choices that they as gay people
are making today I'm trying to
understand why nobody wants to hear that
we're dying why nobody wants to help
what my own brother doesn't want to help
if you're gay you're always fighting for
something it doesn't matter what it is
committed to be absolutely smallest
thing but
not a day that goes by even now that you
don't think like I have to fight for
that it's normal but it's not normal
even in New York
